capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
1. Existence of a centralized information system producing information for decision making in Ministry of Economics and Ministry of Education. 2. Number of Data produced through the information systems
.

comment.narrative: Baseline: 1. Does not exist 2. 0
1. Yes: System in operation. 2. 3

1. Existencia de un sistema en el Ministerio de Economía, y dos sistemas en el Ministerio de Educación.
2. En el MINED: • Servicio de Transporte para Viajes de Misión Oficial y Servicio de Auditoría Interna de Fondos asignados a Entidades de Educación del País • Levantamiento de Información del procedimiento de Control Disciplinario. • Parametrización de Información del Servicio. • Estructuración de Información del Servicio en Instrumento SOL • Servicio de Certificación de Títulos y otros documentos de Educación Superior y Servicio de Certificación de Resultados de Pruebas de Educación Media: • Levantamiento de Información del procedimiento • Parametrización de Información del Servicio.
En MINEC: • Selección de temas/medidas económicas. • Identificación de instituciones participantes. • Selección de indicadores generales (macroeconómicos). • Selección de indicadores específicos (sectoriales). • Identificados 180 indicadores. • Fichas llenadas para 150 indicadores. • Desarrollo del módulo de indicadores. • Cargados al sistema 140 indicadores. • Designación de funcionarios para programación y carga de indicadores. • Capacitación de funcionarios. • Reuniones con contrapartes institucionales para evaluar la interoperabilidad

description.narrative: Proportion of people from targeted population (disaggregated and incl. most vulnerable women and girls) who perceive that their equality and human rights status have improved. Number of gender sensitive measures such policies, papers, internal decrees, strategies, projects, programs) developed and adopted by national institutions that improve legal status of women and girls and contribute to reduce gender base violence and promote gender equality. Number of municipal action plans and SDC work plans that are gender mainstreamed.

comment.narrative: Strengthened institutional mechanisms and policies for improving and promoting gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls. 1200 LCRP partners (particularly civil society organizations, including women rights organizations) deliver a more gender-based response to the impact of the crisis (policies, strategies, programmes, and projects). 1110 Improved capacities of national institutions (MoSA, MoIM, OMSAR, Parliament) to review, develop, promote, pass, and implement gender sensitive policies, strategies, projects and programmes.

1. Strengthened institutional mechanisms and policies for improving and promoting gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls; and 2. LCRP partners (particularly civil society organizations, including women rights organizations) deliver a more gender-based response to the impact of the crisis (policies, strategies, programme and projects). 3. Significant changes in lives of women and girls (Lebanese and Syrian) happen; 4. More budget for gender sensitive programmes is allocated; and 5. Women and girls’ human rights are protected.

capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1. Number of front-line health workers provided with personal protective equipment 2. Number of people reached through PSA in accessible format by June 2020 3. Socio-economic response and recovery framework available 4. Number of most vulnerable people received socio-economic support 5. Number of provincial and local governments reporting improved internal and external crisis communication and response to COVID-19

comment.narrative: 1. Provision of PPEs to health workers 2. Reached at least 500,000 through crisis communication 3. Socio-economic and recovery framework in place 4. 1000 5. 753

- RNA extraction machines and PPEs were provided to provincial governments to support in combatting the crisis - At least 3 millions people were reached through crisis communication via local FM radios and other radio programes. - Over 200 state and non-state frontline actors were trained on crises communication. - The internal and external crisis communication of provincial and local governments has been significantly improved during the COVID-19 crisis through provision of zoom licenses to all seven provinces and 753 local governments. - Socio Economic Response Framework is developed - Most vulnerable people received immediate socio-economic supports

description.narrative: 1. Rehabilitation progress and operability status of SEM building. 2. Number of sets of firefighting and rescue equipment. 3. comment.narrative: 1. 25% 2. 10 sets of firefighting equipment and 10 sets of rescue equipment for MRSS. 3. 45 vehicles, 975 sets of uniforms, and 1 set of mobile dams. 4. 15 transport operations and 721 tons of medical supplies. 5. 10% of technical documentation for reconstruction and extension developed 6. 30 trained local servants. 7. Equipment for MRSS procured.

1. Supported development of technical documentation for reconstruction of the SEM facility. 2. 10 sets of firefighting equipment procured and 10 sets of rescue equipment delivered to MRSS. 3. 12 ambulance and 2 decontamination vehicles delivered; 75 protective sets of uniforms delivered; 27 firefighting vehicles contracted and 3 of them delivered; 4 vehicles delivered to MRSS; 1 set of mobile dams delivered; 900 sets of uniforms contracted and 600 delivered to civil protection units. 4. 15 transport operations supported and 721 tons of medical supplies delivered. 5. 10% of technical documentation for reconstruction and extension developed. 6. E learning module content developed, curricula developed, a pool of 29 trainers established and equipped for delivering local level training. 7. Technical specifications prepared. 8. Technical preconditions for development in place.

description.narrative: 1.1 Online platform for raising awareness on COVID-19 is operational 1.2 # of views of the online platform 1.3 Types of official/authorized guidance and information on COVID-19 shared through the online platform 1.4 # of medical labs supported by UNDP with priority medical equipment to strengthen capacities for testing for COVID-19 1.5 # of designated health-care facilities supported by UNDP to strengthen the healthcare systems to respond to COVID-19 1.6 # of bed capacity equipped treat cases of COVID-19 1.7 # of airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) rehabilitated with UNDP support 2.1 # of coordination meetings facilitated among the UN Country Team on the post-COVID-19 recovery response 2.2 UNCT Iraq’s multi-sectoral post COVID-19 Recovery Strategy developed 2.3 # of people reached through social cohesion activities (gender and youth disaggregated) 3.1 # of socioeconomic needs and impact assessments completed 3.2 Impact Assessment Findings/Report Disseminated 3.3 # of post-COVID-19 recovery strategies identified to be supported by UNDP in Iraq

1.1. Online platform is operational 1.2. At least 40,000 views of the online platform 1.3. As a minimum WHO, Ministry of Health and other official/authorized guidance and information on COVID-19 provided. 1.4. 3 (three) medical labs supported 1.5 16 designated healthcare facilities supported with personal protective equipment (PPE) 1.6. 16 designated healthcare facilities supported by UNDP for strengthened capacities to respond to COVID-19 1.7. 300 airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) rehabilitated 2.1. 6 (six) meetings facilitated 2.2. UNCT Iraq’s Multi-Sectoral post COVID-19 Response Strategy developed 2.3 At least 25,000 more people reached through social cohesion activities (gender and age disaggregated) 3.1.At least 3 assessments to be undertaken 3.2.Impact Assessment Report shared with GoI, UNCT and development partners 3.3. Post-covid-19 recovery strategies identified to be supported by UNDP Iraq

Results as of 13 December 2020 1.1. Online platform, 'Corona in Iraq' is operational 1.2. 192,181 views of the online platform 1.3. The platform established in partnership with the Government of Iraq (GOI), provides information that is provided by the relevant authorities including the Ministry of Health and Environment, WHO and UNICEF. 1.4. Not completed. 1.5 8,160 N95 respirators delivered to 9 facilities. 1.6. Medical equipment including ventilators, defibrillators, patient monitors and suction devices delivered to 8 facilities. 1.7. 238 AIIRs rehabilitated in 13 facilities. 2.1. Regular meetings were facilitated in forms including UNCT, PMT, PWG meetings. 2.2. UNCT Iraq’s Socio-economic Response Plan (SERP) is approved by UN RDCO and available in English and Arabic. 2.3. 64,181 people reached through social cohesion activities (gender and age disaggregated) 3.1. 3 assessments were completed and published in 2020 3.2. 3 Impact Assessment Reports were shared with GoI, UNCT and development partners 3.3. Not completed

description.narrative: Los productos y actividades propuestos en este Plan de Iniciación responden tanto a las prioridades del gobierno como a su solicitud de apoyo, y articulan el soporte brindado por sus socios y donantes. Estos se encuentran alineados con la Estrategia Global de PNUD para dar respuesta a la pandemia provocada por COVID-19, el Plan estratégico de acción y preparación de la OMS / OPS, y el plan de respuesta inter agencial de Naciones Unidas, con el fin de potenciar la articulación y la eficacia de acción desde las capacidades del Sistema de Naciones Unidas en su conjunto.

description.narrative: Support to effective provision of healthcare services. It includes support relevant government agencies and bodies in the framework of COVID19 response
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Procurement health equipment and advocacy for resilient services

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. # health workers in frontline services for COVID-19 response received incentive 2. # medicines and health equipment procured by UNDP

comment.narrative: 1. Unclear delivery mechanism in place to ensure effective and accurate delivery of incentive for health worker 2. The Ministry of Health is experiencing insufficiency of PPE, health equipment and medicines for disease prevention measures to be distributed to the referral health facilities
1. At least, one incentive scheme developed and operational within the ministry 2. 3 ventilators and requested PPE procured for Ministry of Health

To help ease the burden placed on the health care system, UNDP, in partnership with WHO and IOM, donated 45 ventilators to MoH for use by 18 designated referral hospitals through NDMA. 500,000 medical masks distributed to MoFA and NDMA which was supported by China Soong Ching Ling Foundation and facilitated by UNDP China and 30 additional ventilators are currently procured in 2020. In 2020, UNDP provided support for the management of medical waste through the donation of 4 incinerators for government laboratories and 4 autoclaves for referral hospitals, including installation and training for medical waste management officers.
UNDP also has provided technical support to MoH in strengthening protection for health workers on the front line; provided a collaborative framework for telemedicine, and for the development of policies, protocols, and the expansion of a vaccine supply chain monitoring system into a logistics system during the COVID-19 pandemic.
These contribution has been notable to remark UNDP contribution to response the situation of COVID19, in especially in early outbreaks.

description.narrative: (1) 1,000 refugees and host communities’ households are trained in environmental management practices (Water and environment plan intervention 2.4.5 – training and sensitisation session at household level) (2) 1,000 refugees and host communities individuals (60% women) have engaged in environmentally friendly livelihood activities (Water and environment plan intervention 2.4.5 – training and sensitisation session at household level) (3) Two milestones from the CRRF action plan are successfully delivered i.e a) the finalisation and launch of a job and livelihood plan for refugee and host communities and b) the undertaking of a local authority capacity gap assessment towards the streamlining of capacity strengthening initiative (4) One priority intervention identified within the CRRF Water and environment planned is implemented in Lamwo district (5) Number of local government authorities trained on integrating the CRRF agenda into local governance structure and processes (A minimum of 50 LGs)

description.narrative:
3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic a) National government entities b) Sub-national government entities
2.3.2.2: Whether the country has measures in place to address gender-based violence (GBV) during the COVID-19 pandemic, which a) integrate violence prevention and response into COVID-19 response plans b) raise awareness through advocacy and campaigns, with targeted messages to both women and men c) provide options for women to report abuse and seek help without alerting perpetrators d) ensure continued functioning of shelters for victims of violence and expand their capacity e) ensure access to justice build capacity of key services to prevent impunity of perpetrators and protect women and their children

comment.narrative:
a) 2 (Q3= 1 Q4 = 1) (Description: - Technical assistance provided to NDMA for finance, procurement and logistics - Technical experts engaged with Federal Ministry of Health to support communication, data analysis and public health research)
b) 7 (Q3= 4 Q4 = 3) (Description: - Established a human rights task force with the Federal Ministry of Human Rights to ensure a rights-based approach to relief and recovery efforts from COVID-19. The task force developed a detailed strategy with short, medium and long term targets and recommendations to not only ensure inclusive COVID-19 recovery, but also better preparedness against other disasters in Pakistan - 5 virtual courts established in Khber Pakhtunkhwa and Merged Areas - 2 zoom licenses provided to Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Police, 1 to Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Bar Council and 1 to Peshawar High Court to ensure business continuity. - Tehsil Municipal Administrations (TMAs) with the support of Local Government Ambassadors (LGAs) in various districts and tehsil sub-divisions conducted disinfection activities, distributed sanitization supplies and conducted awareness raising sessions. - Strengthened the capcity of five Depty Commissioner (DC) offices (North Waziristan, South Waziristan, Khyber, Kurram, and Orakzai districts) of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa government through provision of IT and Communication equipment for business continuity.)

description.narrative: UNDP COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility Resources. Ensure social stability in the country. Conduct analysis of direct socio-economic impact of the crisis and its spillover effects on the most vulnerable groups of Kazakhstan population.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: A rapid assessment of the COIVID-crisis impact on the most vulnerable to help the Government recalibrate support measures accordingly

comment.narrative: No analysis has been done to date on direct socio-economic impact of the COVID-crisis and its spillover effects on the most vulnerable groups of Kazakhstan population

1) Development of questionnaires for various categories of the population. Identification of target groups. 2) Conducting a nationwide survey of 12,000 respondents through the Talap mobile app, upgraded for visually impaired people. 3) Data analysis, development of anti-crisis package of offers and services, presentation of the results to the key stakeholders. 4) Development of a recovery strategy and action plan informed by the results of the following two components.

1) For technical implementation, UNDP has partnered with a national think tank “TALAP” that has a deep understanding of the development context and the current situation. “TALAP” spearheaded the development of the questionnaires, with the key stakeholders from the UN agencies and the government providing their input on the questionnaire content. The key target groups covered were: SMEs and self-employed, population, including vulnerable social groups, namely the economically active population, elderly and/or single people, persons with disabilities, disadvantaged and other vulnerable categories, parents with children under 6 years of age, as well as the key stakeholders in education and healthcare. 2) The overall sample amounted to 12,067 participants across all 14 regions and 3 key cities of the country. The survey was conducted from 5 May to 10 June 2020. 3) According to the SEIA, a deterioration of the financial situation caused by quarantine measures is noted by 51% of the unemployed, 45% of low-income people, 42% of persons with disabilities, 36% of the economically active population. Quarantine measures and the state of emergency heavily impacted the most vulnerable groups of the population, as demonstrated by the indirect indicators: 40% of the unemployed and 38% of low income people reported that they could not afford enough food; 43% of the unemployed and low income people reported difficulties paying for utilities; 38% of the unemployed and 47% of low income people had to borrow money and/or take loans to pay for staple commodities. Covid-19 is devastating small businesses, currently employing 3.3 mln. people. 69.6% of SMEs were forced to suspend their economic activities and another 2.2% completely stopped operating during the quarantine. Self-employed people suffered even more, with 71% suspending their activities due to the introduction of quarantine measures. Women-entrepreneurs were more affected by quarantine measures and the state of emergency than men: during the period of quarantine, 69% of women-owned SMEs stopped their activities, compared with 59% of men-entrepreneurs. The results of the SEIA were presented to the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, and other stakeholders including IFIs. 4) The United Nations Country Team (UNCT) developed Kazakhstan´s COVID-19 Socio-Economic Response & Recovery Plan, guided by the global UN Framework for the Immediate Socio-economic Response to COVID-19´s five pillars, the UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2021-2025), the Common Country Analysis, the Socio-Economic Impact Assessment (SEIA), as well as the wider regional Framework on Socio-Economic Response to COVID-19.

description.narrative: Le projet vise deux résultats principaux: 1) dispositif national facilitant l’accès au droit en particulier pour les couches vulnérables de la population, est renforcé 2.) Le Ministère des droits de l’homme est durablement renforcé en vue de collaborer efficacement avec les mécanismes internationaux et régionaux des droits de l’homme, de promouvoir la généralisation de l’approche basée sur les droits de l’homme et de protéger les droits fondamentaux des couches vulnérables de la population.

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Sustaining progress towards the SDGs in Nepal in the time of the COVID pandemic is expected to serve as short- and medium-term response to the socio-economic crisis including comprehensive long-term programmatic response.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. Number of provinces with at least one functional SDG platform by December 2020 2. # of sub-national governments prepared and implementing SDG based period plan with UNDP support by March 2021 3. # of sub-national governments developed and piloted SDG Report Card for SDG monitoring by March 2021 4. Number of crisis-affected most vulnerable people (men and women, migrants, seasonal workers, people with disabilities) supported through selected socio-economic activities to restore their livelihoods by March 2021 5. Number of sub-national government supported with basic infrastructure and logistics for timely response to Covid-19 outbreak by June 2020 6. Number of government officials trained on crisis management, effective communication and community resilience by June 2020 7. Number of joint projects formulated with funding commitments from the private sector, government, UN agencies and other partners. 8. Revised Resource Mobilization strategy in place

comment.narrative: - Three Provinces have finalized the SDG platform Themes and potential organization (Province 2 on Resilient Cities-Extraction of Natural Resources, Gandaki Province- Green Finance and Karnalai Province- Food Security) are finalized - 11 local governments prepared the periodic plan and start implementing - UNDP has developed and rolled out a dedicated socio-economic and livelihood recovery package. The package program aims to increase the basic income of vulnerable groups by promoting local resource-based enterprises- on farm based and off farmed. - 12,386 households were directly benefitted from socio-economic recovery interventions to improve their income and livelihood - 18 socio-economic recovery project in partnerships with municipalities implemented.
- Three SDG platforms established in 2020 will be functional

description.narrative:
1.1.2.3 Nbr de diagnostic stratégique sur le développement des TPPE et auto-entrepreneurs et à leur transition de l’informel vers le formel 1.1.3.1. Nbr de réunions multipartites organisées
2.4.1.1. Nbr de projets prometteurs identifiés 2.4.2.1. Nbr de projets lancés et accompagnés 2.4.2.2 % de projets portés par des jeunes hommes et femmes (19 – 35 ans) 2.4.2.3. % de projets portés par des femmes 2.4.2.4. % de personnes vulnérables (handicap, sous le seuil de pauvreté, habitant en zone rurale à très faible densité etc.) 2.4.2.5. % de projets d’économie sociale et solidaire portés 2.4.3.1. Satisfaction des entrepreneurs accompagnés
2.6.3.2. Nbr de partenariats financiers et techniques établis 2.6.4.1. Nbr de concours entrepreneuriaux organisés dans les écoles, universités et centres de formation professionnelle 2.6.4.2 % de femmes participantes au concours entrepreneuriaux

comment.narrative:
1.1.2.3 UN diagnostic stratégique sur le développement des TPPE et auto-entrepreneurs et à leur transition de l’informel vers le formel 1.1.3.1. TROIS réunions multipartites organisées
2.4.1.1. Nbr de projets prometteurs identifiés 2.4.2.1. Nbr de projets lancés et accompagnés 2.4.2.2 % de projets portés par des jeunes hommes et femmes (19 – 35 ans) 2.4.2.3. % de projets portés par des femmes 2.4.2.4. % de personnes vulnérables (handicap, sous le seuil de pauvreté, habitant en zone rurale à très faible densité etc.) 2.4.2.5. % de projets d’économie sociale et solidaire portés 2.4.3.1. Satisfaction des entrepreneurs accompagnés
2.6.3.2. Nbr de partenariats financiers et techniques établis 2.6.4.1. Nbr de concours entrepreneuriaux organisés dans les écoles, universités et centres de formation professionnelle 2.6.4.2 % de femmes participantes au concours entrepreneuriaux

1.1.2.3 DEUX diagnostic stratégique sur le développement des TPPE et auto-entrepreneurs et à leur transition de l’informel vers le formel (desk review chaines de valeur, Etude Miqyes COVID) 1.1.3.1. NEUF réunions multipartites organisées
2.4.1.1. 230 projets prometteurs identifiés 2.4.2.1. 131 projets lancés et accompagnés 2.4.2.2 4 projets portés par des jeunes hommes et femmes (19 – 35 ans) 2.4.2.3. 55% de projets portés par des femmes 2.4.2.4. 76% de personnes vulnérables (handicap, sous le seuil de pauvreté, habitant en zone rurale à très faible densité etc.) 2.4.2.5. 65 % de projets d’économie sociale et solidaire portés
2.6.3.2. TROIS partenariats financiers et techniques établis (avec Ettijari Bank, Orange et Enactus)
